Edilberto, as a newly recognized member of PMPC under the Regular Loan Program, is now requesting a first loan of 20,000.00 PHP to be used as additional capital for his existing sari-sari store and little eatery business. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family, especially in meeting his basic needs, saving for a future use, loan repayments, insurance and possible business expansions. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for his sari-sari (general) store and little eatery business

loans.name: Phoeun

texts.en:
Mr. Phoeun K., age 34 (pictured here) and his wife, Mrs. Nang Un, age 31, are vegetable farmers. The couple does not have their own transportation for commuting, which means that they must spend a considerable amount of money on traveling costs. Phoeun has decided to ask for his first loan in the amount of $600, which will be used to purchase a motorcycle. He will also apply some of the loan money toward his farming business. 

He and his wife live in a suburb of Phnom Penh, about 15 kilometers from the city. They have been married since 1998 and have two sons and a daughter. Two of the children are in school and the youngest is still very small.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for commuting.

loans.name: Enhbold

texts.en:
Enhbold H., age 30, makes wooden products which he and his wife sell in their store. He began his business last year, shortly after resigning from a local furniture manufacturing company. His considerable experience in this kind of work has allowed him to begin this business and to make it successful. His wife works as a saleswoman in the store. 

He is a very busy man, building custom-made items throughout the day according to client orders. He is a creative and hardworking person who wishes to expand his business by hiring more employees in the future. He tells us, "My only wish now is to finish building my two-story house, which will greatly improve my family's quality of life." He and his wife live with their daughter in the central province of Mongolia.

Enhbold is requesting a 700,000 MNT loan to purchase more wood, necessary tools, and equipment for his wood manufacturing business.

loans.use: To purchase more wood, necessary tools, and equipment

loans.name: Estelita

texts.en:
Estelita E., age 59, owns and operates a general store in the town of Turod Norte, Cordon. Estelita has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month from these activities. Estelita has seven grown children.
 
Estelita joined ASKI earlier this year to gain access to financial services. She hoped to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Estelita is requesting a loan in the amount of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Estelita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell in her store

loans.name: Khorn

texts.en: Mrs. Khorn L. is a villager in Trapeang Khchau village, Takeo province. She was born in 1951 and she is a farmer who owns a one point five-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Although she tries to work hard, she can earn very  little money to support her family. So to improve this condition, Mrs. Khorn L. is asking for a loan to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business, and the rest of the loan she will use to buy two piglets, also for breeding, to start a second new business. She is a widow with a child who is studying in school.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding to start a new business

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina A., age 46, is a vegetable vendor in the village of Villa Concepcion, Cauayan City, Isabela. Lina is just starting this business and plans to expand it over time in order to gain more income. She is married and has three school-aged children.  

Lina joined ASKI earlier this year to gain access to financial services. Her goal was to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Lina is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional vegetable products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional vegetable products to sell

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites T., age 48, owns and operates a specialized retail store in the village of San Jose, Enrile, Cagayan, where she sells second-hand clothes to local community members. Marites has been engaged in her business for over a year now and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month from these activities.

Marites joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. She wished to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Marites has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. She is now requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in renovating the business. This will be the third loan taken out by Marites from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. Marites is widowed and has three school-aged children.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in renovating the business

loans.name: Ganbaatar

texts.en:
Ganbaatar C. is 36 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Bayanhongor province, central Mongolia, in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His two children attend a local primary school while his wife helps him out with his consumer goods retailing and a taxi service.

Ganbaatar and his family manage their retailing business out of a small, rented stall at a market in their town. Ganbaatar has been operating it since 1998 and his  business methods and experience have improved, and the number of his sales channels has also increased. 

Since 2000, Ganbaatar has been doing a transportation service with a big Russian truck as well as selling consumer goods throughout his province. Ganbaatar and his wife Odontuya wish to expand their retailing business and would like to one day purchase a convenient apartment where the family could live more comfortably. 

Ganbaatar is a hardworking and open-minded man who would like to keep growing his business further. He is requesting a 2,000,000 Mongolian tugriks loan in order to purchase a large amount of food to sell in the market and increase his working capital as well.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of food

loans.name: Edwin

texts.en: Edwin B. is from the village of San Jose, Enrile, Cagayan. He is 35 years old. Edwin is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Edwin operates a transportation business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing horse-drawn cart services to local community members. Edwin has been engaged in his business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Edwin joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edwin is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP for the repair and maintenance of the push cart used in the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Edwin from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For the repair and maintenance of the push cart used in the business

loans.name: Rafia's Group

texts.en:
Rafia is a resident of a city called Borewala, which is located in the Punjab province of Pakistan. She lives in a two-room brick house with her husband and three children. She has two sons and a daughter. Her eldest son is in 10th standard, the youngest one reads in 2nd standard and her daughter reads in 9th standard.  

Rafia is in the carpet-weaving industry. She collects orders from factories and different carpet sellers and weaves carpets on order to earn an income. She complete one carpet in a two-month time frame and earns a good income on it.  

She is a very good housewife and mother as well. She gives the required time to her family and takes care of them very well. 

Her husband runs a grocery shop in the market. His business is giving him a good return. In this way, they both are managing their family expenses. Although they are working very hard, still they are facing financial problems and are unable to pay for their kids' education expenses.  

Therefore, Rafia has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount he will buy the groceries in bulk and increases the profit of his business. She is hopeful that this investment will help them to save some profit for the future of their kids and they will easily pay off their education expenses as well. 

She is in her second loan cycle and is a very responsible loan user of Asasah. In the previous year, she has maintained good credit behavior and never missed a meeting.

loans.use: Purchase groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Sakina

texts.en:
Sakina lives in a big city in Pakistan called Lahore. Lahore is famous for its culture, history and food. She lives in the area of Lahore named Yadgar, which has its own historic importance: the 1947 Pakistan resolution passed in Yadgar. Sakina is above 40-years of age and lives with her family in a three-room brick house. She is married to H. F. A., who makes shoe boxes on order. He has contracts with different shoe-making companies. They give him orders and he makes the boxes according to different shoes sizes to make an income. His business is going very well and he is making good profits from it. Sakina makes and sells bread. She operates a tandoor (a wood-burning over made of mud that is used to make breads on commercial level in Pakistan) and works very hard in the burning heat all the day to earn a living for her family. Her business is also going well. She sells her bread for 5 PKRs and earns almost 100-150 PKRs on daily basis. Sakina has applied for a loan from Asasah to financially assist her husband, who has large orders to fulfill these days. With the help of the loan, he will buy raw materials that are used to make of shoe boxes, such as hard paper and gum, in large quantities.

Sakina is very confident that her husband will not let her down and that he will make good use of the loan to gain maximum benefits from his business. Sakina is a regular user of Asasah. In the previous three years, she proved to be a responsible member who always paid her loan installments on time.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for making shoe boxes
