texts.en:
Mr. Vanh S. is 40 years old and his wife, Seng Phan, is 38. They work from home making furniture to sell. Most of their output consists of beds, tables and cupboards, which they accumulate and sell as sets. Their furniture is made mostly from wood and rattan. 

The couple has four children, all of whom are in school and also help their parents make furniture. In order to make their business more successful, Vanh S. has applied for an $300 loan to buy raw materials to make furniture to sell. (Mr. Vanh S. was not available when the photograph was taken.)

loans.use: To buy raw materials for making furniture

loans.name: Sophi

texts.en: Mrs. Sophi N., who was born in 1974, lives in Trapeang Lean village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Chhun Seng, sell Chinese noodles in their local village in order to support their family. They are also farmers who own a half-hectare plot of land where they grow rice to sell. Although they work hard, they earn very little money to support their family. To earn more money, Mrs. Sophi N. is seeking a loan to buy six piglets for breeding and pig food in order to start a new business. With the rest of the loan, she will buy fertilizer. This couple has three children, one of whom is a waiter. One is enrolled in a local school, while the youngest one is just eleven months old. Her husband is shown in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy six piglets and pig food

loans.name: Sughran's Group

texts.en:
Sughran lives in a historic city of Pakistan called Lahore. She is 42 years old and lives in the area of Yadgar, in Lahore, with her husband and four children. 

Due to financial constraints, Sughran couldn’t educate her children. As a result they couldn’t find good jobs, but her two elder sons somehow manage to earn some money by driving and performing labor. Her husband operates a donkey cart. He sells vegetables by putting them on the cart and visiting street to street. Sughran is a housewife and does her household responsibilities by staying at home. 

Life is not easy for Sughran’s family but now she wants to change the fortune of her family by improving the business of her husband. She has applied for a loan from Asasah to purchase a young donkey for her husband because his current donkey has grown old and he wants young one who can work for more hours for him and can bear more load then the old one.  Sughran hopes that her husband will be able to do well and his income will grow.

loans.use: Purchase a young donkey for his vegetable selling business

loans.name: Koem Lean

texts.en: Mrs. Koem Lean L. lives in Prey Chheu Teal village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a two-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice, which she sells to support her family. She is a widow with two children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory, while the other is employed by a private company. Although she tries to work hard, she earns very little money to support her family. To earn more money, Mrs. Koem Lean L. is applying for a loan to buy two mother pigs for breeding and pig food in order to start a new business.

loans.use: To buy two pigs and pig food

loans.name: Sun

texts.en:
Mr. S. is a 52-year-old married man who currently resides in the middle of Kompong Tom, the province of Cambodia. He is an internal staff officer who works in the protecting mine industry. He started his job more than four years ago. 

S. is blessed with three children; one is already married and the other two are single. His wife works as a local chef for wedding parties and also spends time at home to do housework. 

This family has been planning to build a new home but the construction processes have not been able to  start because of a lack of essential material. Therefore, S. decided to request a loan of $800 to buy equipment in order to build a new house. (Mr. S.'s wife is pictured.)

loans.use: To buy equipment in order to build a new house

loans.name: Mrs. Touch Chea Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Touch C., 41 years old, has been selected as the group leader by 14 people seeking a group loan. The group is located in Kampong Luong village, Takeo province. Each member of the group will use a portion of the loan for a different purpose; all members will use the proceeds from the loan investment to support their families. Mrs. Touch C. and her husband, Mr. Ly K., are farmers who own a two-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice, which they sell. She also breeds pigs. Since her pig breeding is going well, she wants to expand. To improve her business, Mrs. Touch C. is applying for a loan to buy more pig food. She is the mother of four children: one is a farmer, while the others are attending school.

loans.use: To buy pig food

loans.name: Meas

texts.en:
Meas K. is 41 years of age and is a married woman. In order to meet the needs of the family, Meas K. sells a few food products out of the primary school. She sells items like candy, cake and snack food for kids. She has four years of experience in this sector and is earning approximately $5 per day. She also receives help for producing and selling cakes from her husband. 

This couple has been married for years and they have six kids who are teenagers. One of their daughters is employed in the garment factory. 

Meas K. will be using the loan she requested to build a medium workshop in front of her home, where she will live and operate her investment.

loans.use: To build a medium workshop in front of her home where she will live and operate her investment.

loans.name: Bushra's Group

texts.en:
Bushra is a resident of a historic city of Pakistan called Lahore. Lahore is a capital city of the Punjab province and is known for its culture and history. 

Bushra is a 42-year-old woman who came to Lahore after her marriage with M. N., who makes and sells artificial flowers. Artificial flowers are used as a decorative material in decoration pieces and at different functions and parties. 

Bushra also helps her husband in his business. She learned this art from him and now she makes equally good quality flowers as her husband. 

She is a mother of three sons and two daughters and lives in a three-room brick house. Bushra only managed to send her eldest daughter to school till 5th standard. All of her other children couldn’t get an education due to limited financial resources. Now two out of her three sons work in their own motor workshop, where they repair vehicles. 

Bushra has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband, who wants to make a larger quantity of artificial flowers to increase his income. With the help of a loan, he will buy raw materials in bulk, such as artificial flower petals and the plastic sticks used in the making of flowers. 

Bushra is very confident that by making an investment in her family business, their income will be increased and their family’s financial condition will get better. She is in her fourth loan cycle and is a responsible loan user of Asasah. In her previous years of loan experience, she has paid her installments on time and never missed a meeting.

loans.use: Purchase raw material for making artificial flowers

loans.name: Mrs. Kun Chhoem Village Bank Group

texts.en: This group loan is for eleven people who live in Kampong Luong village, Takeo province. All group members will use a portion of the loan in different ways to support their businesses. Mrs. Kun C., who was born in 1962, has been selected by the other members as the group leader. She and her husband, Mr. Lan Nai, are farmers who own a four-hectare plot of land where they grows crops, which they sell to support their family. Mrs. Kun C.'s problem is that her fields needs to be prepared to grow crops, but she does not have enough money. To improve production, she is applying for a loan for her farming expenses this current year. She is the mother of four children: three are farmers, while the other is attending school.

loans.use: Farming expenses

loans.name: Sharifan's Group

texts.en:
Sharifan belongs to a famous city called Lahore. Lahore is the second largest city of Pakistan and is known for its history and culture. She lives in the area named Yadgar, which is situated in Lahore. Her house consists of three rooms. 

She is an old lady aged more than 50 who makes artificial flowers to financially support her family. She purchases raw materials from a wholesale market and makes beautiful artificial flowers to order. Her husband sells candies and toffees and her only son also has this same business.
 
Sharifan couldn’t provide an education to her son and he had started doing work for his family’s financial survival. 

Sharifan has applied for a loan from Asasah for her son, who wants to improve his business by supplying a larger quantity of toffees and candies. With the loan amount, he will buy the candies and toffees in a larger quantity, which enables him to fulfill larger orders and increase his income.
 
Sharifan is in her fourth loan cycle and is a responsible loan user of Aasah. She always attended all the meetings and has maintained a good credit record.

loans.use: Purchase candies and toffees on a wholesale basis for reselling

loans.name: Ngin

texts.en:
The middle-aged woman in the photograph is Ngin S., age 37. She lives in the province of Kompong Chhnang, which is the best territory for farming. Ngin S. is a married mother who is devoted to her three young children. One of her daughters is no longer in school and currently works in the garment industry. 

Ngin S. owns a big farm that she inherited from her grandmother. She grows various crops on it. She also relies on the income from her husband, who works in the building field. Ngin S. will be using part of the loan to support her husband for buying construction tools and the rest to buy rice in bulk to resell for extra income.

loans.use: To buy rice in bulk to resell for extra income

loans.name: Mira's Group

texts.en: Mira S. is the leader of the group. She is 41 and married. She has a daughter and a son; the son is at school and the daughter is not yet. Mira owns a shop to sell convenience goods and her husband works in construction. When he is free, he helps Mira with her activity. Mira opened her shop three years ago and she makes 5,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase a variety of convenience goods in order to increase the turnover of her business. In the future, she wants to expand her business and purchase a vehicle. Raiymbubu N. is the treasurer of the group. She is 41 and married. She has four children. Her husband works in the factory. Ten years ago, with the initial investment of 500 soms, Raiymbubu started to take orders and sew with the national cloth and dressmaking supplies. In this way, she makes 5,000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to purchase a new sewing machine. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase fabrics and materials. In the future, she wants to see her sons get wed. Vera C., 46, is married. She has four children. In order to cover family expenses, Vera started to sew with the national cloth and dressmaking supplies. She has been doing it for 13 years. In this way, she earns 6,000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to improve her living conditions and purchase a new fridge. Vera applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase fabrics and materials. In the future, she wants to expand her business and save some money to contribute to her daughter’s wedding. Kerimkul T., 45, is married. He has four children; a daughter and a son are at school and the other children are working. Kerimkul is a taxi driver and his wife works in the ice cream shop. Kerimkul applied for the loan because he needs money to repair his vehicle. In the future, he wants to purchase a house for his older son. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of convenience goods to increase the turnover of her business

loans.name: Va

texts.en: Va K. is a 44-year-old widowed woman and a local villager living in a medium-sized home with family members in Kompong Chhnang Province. She owns a piece of farmland that she uses to grow different kinds of crops. She planted rice and vegetable crops two months ago, but her crops are not growing well because they need more fertilizer. To remedy the situation, she would like a loan to buy sacks of fertilizer to fatten her crop yield.

loans.use: To buy sacks of fertilizer to fatten her crop yield

loans.name: Suraiya's Group

texts.en:
Suraiya is a resident of Lahore, which is Pakistan’s second largest city and the capital of Punjab province. 

She is thirty-seven years old and lives in a small house with her family. She is the mother of a son and a daughter. Both are illiterate and her son has a fruit-selling business. 

Suraiya supports her family by making and selling artificial flowers. She is very skillful in her art and earns a good income every month. Her husband sells seasonal fruits and works in the fruit market.  

Suraiya’s husband wants to increase his income by improving his fruit selling business for which he needs investment. Therefore, Suraiya has applied for a loan from Asasah to invest in her husband’s fruit selling business. She is confident that her husband will make positive use of the loan money and will be able to increase his income. 

Suraiya’s daughter is getting older and she wants to marry her within a year. She hopes that increased profits will help her do so. 

Suraiya is in her 4th loan cycle and is a responsible loan user of Asasah. In her previous years of loan experience, she has maintained good credit behavior and never missed any meetings.

loans.use: Purchase fruits for reselling

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Srey S. is a 53-year-old villager living in a medium-sized home with family members in Kompong Chhnang Province. She was married but her husband died of senility and she now has three children. One is now married and the other two are single. 

Srey S. is a local cultivator who is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer to improve her crops that are not growing well.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to improve her crops

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen is 30 years old and lives in the historic city of Lahore, Pakistan.  he lives in a small home with her husband and two children in the area of Yadgar. Both of her children are sons; they are very young and have not started attending school yet. Her husband is a rickshaw driver. He works very hard to put three meals on the table. Her father also lives with her and works in a factory for a low income.

Nasreen makes artificial flowers on order. She was doing this before her marriage (for 14 years); when she was very young, she learned this art from her mother. 
 
Nasreen has applied for a loan from Asasah for her artificial flower business. With the loan, she will buy the raw materials such as artificial flower petals and plastic sticks in large quantities, and she will hire a worker to  assist her in making artificial flowers to fulfill larger orders on time.  She will train the assistant about flower making. 

She hopes that she will be able to increase her income by making these changes to her business and thereby improve her family's living standard. She is in her 2nd loan cycle and is a responsible loan user of Asasah.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for making artificial flowers

loans.name: Rehana's Group

texts.en:
Rehana lives in a big city called Lahore, which is the second largest city of Pakistan. She is 36 years old and has given birth to 2 sons and a daughter. Rehana couldn’t educate her children due to poor financial conditions. Now one of her son works in the field as a farmer. 

Rehana works in the fruit and vegetable market to support her family financially. She sells vegetables and seasonal fruits there to contribute financially to her family. 

Her husband sells milk; he has been in that  business for the past ten years. He puts milk in milk jars and uses his motorbike to deliver it to door to door. 

Rehana has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband, who wants to buy a buffalo to increase milk production. She is very confident that a new young buffalo will be a great addition to the business of her husband and he will be able to sell a larger quantity of milk, which will obviously makes him more income. 

Rehana has a plan to construct a room for the cattle so her husband keeps his buffalos in there. She is hopeful that increased profits will help her achieve her plan to keep the buffalos safe from heat and rain. 

She is a regular user of Asasah. She is in her 3rd loan cycle and has always paid installments on time and proved to be a very responsible client.

Note: In this photo, Rehana is showing her vegetables happily.

loans.use: To purchase another buffalo for dairy business

loans.name: Myskal's Group

texts.en:
Myskal A. is the leader of the group. She is 75 and married. She has raised seven children; most of them are married and live separately.  The first son and the first daughter are bookkeepers, the second son is a musician, the second daughter works in a sewing workshop; and the other children went to work in Russia.  Myskal herself is engaged in poultry, she has been doing it for 45 years. By selling the eggs and chickens, Myskal makes 1200 soms per month. With the money received from the loan, she wants to purchase chickens and a cow for breeding. 

Aichurek A., 57, is married. She has a daughter; the daughter is married and lives in Osh.  Aichurek herself works as a teacher at school, and she also engaged in cattle breeding. With the money from the loan, she wants to purchase hay for her cattle. 

Gulnara T. is the treasurer of the group. She is 50 and divorced. She has raised two sons and two daughters.  The sons went to work in Russia; the first daughter studies at university; and the second is at school.  Three years ago with an initial investment of 50000 soms, Gulnara opened her own shop near the house. She sells convenience goods and makes 7000 soms per month.  That profit made it possible for her to purchase household appliances and improve her living conditions. With the money from the loan, she wants to purchase a variety of convenience goods and also 150 watermelons in order to resell them at a higher price. 

Kurmanjan A., 62, is married. She has three sons and two daughters, most of them are married and live separately with their families.  Kurmanajan and her husband are engaged in cattle breeding. Kurmanjan applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase hay to feed the cattle during the winter season. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious, and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly), and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance, at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase chickens and a cow for breeding

loans.name: Nazia's Group

texts.en:
Nazia lives in the historic city of Lahore, Pakistan in a three roomed house with her family. She is 34 years old and has given birth to five children; three daughters and two sons. Her sons are studying in 4th and 5th standard while her daughters are in 5th and kindergarten. 

Nazia is a caring lady who carries out her responsibilities as a housewife and mother very well. She is raising her children with great care. Her husband is employed in a government job, which does not provide enough for the financial expenses of the family. So, in order to fulfill the basic needs of the family, he does a business of selling embroidery material by operating a shop in the market where he sells tassels, beads, beaded laces, etc. Nazia has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s embroidery shop. With the loan amount, he will buy the above-mentioned embroidery items in large quantities to sell in his shop. Nazia hopes that this investment will put a positive impact on her husband’s business and he will be able to get good income from it. She is in her 3rd loan cycle and is a responsible loan user of Asasah.

loans.use: To purchase embroidery materials for selling.

loans.name: Janyl's Group

texts.en:
Janyl K. is the leader of the group. She is 47 and divorced. She has raised three children, all of whom are married and live separately with their families. Janyl works as a teacher at a school. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase building materials to start repairing her house. In the future she wants to purchase a vehicle. 

Nurbubu K. is the treasurer of the group. She is 53 and married. She has five children: thee of them are married and live separately with their families and the other children are students. Her husband works as a security guard in the factory. Eighteen years ago, with the initial investment of 500 soms, Nurbubu started to sew national blankets. Selling the blankets she makes 4000 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase fabrics and materials for sewing. 

Mirbek A. is 24 years old. In order to make money he sells coal in Bishkek and Tokmak. He started this activity a year ago with the initial investment of 3000 soms and now he earns 10000 soms per month. With money received from the loan he wants to purchase more coal to increase the turnover of his business.  

Izaura S. is twenty years old. She helps her mom to sell children’s wear on the market. This year Izaura decided to start her own business. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase currants and strawberries in villages and then resell them at the higher price in the city. Part of the loan, she will spend to purchase clothes to help her mom with her activity. In the future Izaura wants to get married and to save money to purchase a vehicle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase building materials.

loans.name: Mussarat's Group

texts.en:
Mussarat lives in a big city in Pakistan called Lahore. Lahore is the second largest city in Pakistan and the capital of Punjab province. She is 45 years old house wife who spends all day at home in doing her household responsibilities. She has four children, three sons and a daughter. Her eldest son is illiterate and works as a sales man in a cloth selling shop. Her daughter left her education after 5th and also started to work to financially support the family. She does embroidery work. She learned this art from her mother who also does sewing and embroidery in her spare time. Her remaining children are attending school and getting their education. 

Her husband is a rickshaw driver. He works full-time and drives passengers to their destinations to earn a living for his family. He has been driving the rickshaw for the last 15 years. 

Mussarat has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount he will repair his rickshaw because while working for years his engine is now started creating problems. With the overhauled rickshaw her husband will be able to work for longer hours and more efficiently.

loans.use: Repair a rickshaw.

loans.name: Khalida Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Khalida Perveen is 40 years old lady who lives in a historic city of Pakistan called Lahore in a three room brick house for the last 17 years with her husband and a ten years old daughter who is studying in 2nd grade. 
She is a house wife and does her household tasks by staying at home. She takes care of her husband and daughter very well and has a reputation among her family as a great wife and a caring mother. 
She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband who operates a rice dish stall in the market. He sells a special dish made of rice, which is called Biryani, a very popular food here in Pakistan. He is famous in the market for the great taste of his rice dish and has a good client base. With the loan amount he will buy rice, chicken, spices and cooking oil in large quantity which helps him to make Biryani of larger quantity for selling through his stall to make more income.  
Khalida perveen is confident that by using his ten years of experience in this business, her husband will be able to get the desired results from the help of this investment.

loans.use: To purchase required items for Biryani sellling business.

loans.name: Teopista

texts.en: Teopista is widowed with five children and only one of her children goes to school. She also takes care of additional family members. Teopista owns a stall in Busega selling charcoal and bananas. She buys bunches of bananas from the very place where she works and so she doesn’t incur any transportation costs to and from shopping. Besides this charcoal business, she gets additional income from weaving mats. She has been in this business for 6 1/2 years. She sells to all categories of people, on retail. Teopista works six days a week. Her business challenges include thieves and defaulters. She is aspiring to buy a plot of land. She decided to work with MCDT because of they are trust worthy. Teopista resides in and rents a two-roomed house and the family has no access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses includes school fees, rent and food.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Nkeyoni Enole

texts.en:
Nkeiyoni Enole M. is 55 years old and supports three members of her family. Her spouse is Saitoti M. and they are blessed with two children. She has been doing wheat farming successfully for the last ten years. This has been due to good climatic conditions and ready market for the produce in her area.
 
This being her second loan, she is planning to spend 30,000 KES to buy fertilizer and chemicals for her 10-acre wheat farm and the remaining 10,000 on spraying the wheat.

Her plan on the anticipated profits is that she will expand her wheat farming to large scale farming.

Her hope and dream is that she will become a large scale farmer and own some farm machineries.

She is a hardworking woman and determined to achieve her set target.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and chemicals

loans.name: Marmar

texts.ru:
Marmar S. 51  let. Mermer zamujem i imeyet 4 detey, doch 20 let uchitsya v universitete, doch 18 v etom qodu postupila na dizaynera i xochet tak je kak i eyo mama shit razniye interesniye odejdi, sin 16 let uchitsya v shkole i zanimayetsya sportom, i dochka 14 let toje uchitsya v shkole. Marmar  yavlyayetsya IDP personoy, Ona pereselenec iz okupirovannix territoriy Djabraila, seychas ona projivayet v Absheron regione , poselok Biladjari.

Marmar uje 10 let rabotayet partnixoy . Etomu biznessu ona nauchilas u svoyey mami .Maryam s detstva lubila shit ona chasto shila odejdi svoim kuklam i mat uvidem chto doch tak lubit shit ona eyo nauchila professionalnomu sshityu  s tex por ona vse vremya shila odejdu i ochen lubit svoyu rabotu. Seychas Maryam nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit novuyu shveynuyu mashinu dlya razvitiya svoyeqo biznessa.
texts.en:
Marmar S. is 51 years old. Marmar is married and has four children: her 20-year-old daughter is studying at the university, her 18-year-old daughter enrolled in design school this year and wants to work alongside her mama sewing different interesting clothes, her 16-year-old son is in school and loves sports, and her 14-year-old daughter is also in school. Marmar is an internally-displaced person (IDP), she moved location from the occupied Djabraila territory and now she lives in the Absheron region, district Biladjari. Marmar has already been working for 10 years. She began this business alongside her own mother. In her childhood, Maryam loved to sew. She often sewed clothes for her dolls. The mother saw that her daughter loved to sew so much that she taught her professional sewing, such that she spent all her time sewing clothing and very much loves her work. Now, Maryam needs a loan in order to buy a new sewing machine to develop her business.

Translated from Russian by JD Bergeron, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Reuben

texts.en: Reuben N. is a 28 year old single man in the transport business in Magongo, Mombasa. He offers taxi - tuk tuk services and he has been in that business for two years. Reuben supplements his income by selling GNLD products. This loan marks his first borrowing from KADET micro-finance, and he plans to purchase beauty and medical products for his other business and to also service his tuk tuk. His customers are the area residents. Reuben hopes to expand his transport business by purchasing a Nissan matatu in future.

loans.use: To purchase beauty and medical products for his other business and to also service his taxi.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema G. is a 32-year-old Mitumba (used clothing) dealer in Mtwapa Mombasa. She also supplements her income as a part-time tailor in Mtwapa.
She is married to George Tumaini who supports her income. They have four children. Rehema has been in the business for the past 12 years and now is requesting her first loan from KADET.  She plans to purchase a sewing machine with the loan and use the anticipated profit to educate her children. Rehema hopes to own a school uniform shop and a second-hand shop for a variety of items like furniture.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Malakat

texts.ru:
Malakat G. 47 let. Malakat i yeyo semya  yavlayutsya IDP personami ,oni pereselenci iz qoroda Fuzuli seychas oni projivayut v Absheron regione.Vo vremya beqsta iz okkupirovannix territoriy Karabaxa yeyo muj traqicheski poqib i ona ostalas odna s dvuma malenkimi detmi,seychas yeyo deti dochka 19 let uchitsya v universitete i dochka 17 let kotoraya uchitsya v shkole  a tak je zanimayestya tancami. Oni ochen pomoqayut mame po domu i po rabote. 

Malakat uje 5 let zanimayestya etim biznesom prodaji odejdi. Malakat seychas nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi uvelichit pomesheniye. Ryadom s yeyo maqazinom yest mesto kotoroye ona xotelabi prisoyedenit k svoyemu maqazinu i uvelichit yeqo. Seychas Malakat osobo nujdayetsya v etoy ssude iz za toqo chto yeyo deti uchatsya ona tratit na ix uchebu mnoqo  i poetomu ona nujdayetysa uvelichit pomesheniye i nachat prodovat mnoqo novix raznix tovarov i zarabotat bolshe deneg dlya svoyey semyi.
texts.en:
Malakat G. is 47 years old. Malakat and her family are IDPs (internally displaced people); they relocated from the city of Fuzuli and now live in the Absheron region. During the time of their flight from the occupied Karabaxa territory, her husband tragically died and she was left alone with two small children. Now, her 19-year-old daughter goes to college and her 17-year-old daughter is in school and also practices dance. They help their mama very much around the home and at work. Malakat has been engaged in the business of selling clothes for five years already. Malakat now needs a loan in order to expand her place of business. Near her store, there is a space where she would like to combine with her store and improve it. Now, Malakat especially needs this loan, due to the fact that she is lucky enough to be able to send her children to school, and therefore she needs to expand her place of business and to start offering many new and varied products and earn more money for her family.

Translated from Russian by JD Bergeron, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand her place of business

loans.name: Elkanah

texts.en: Elkanah O. is thirty years old, married, and has one child, aged seven. His business, Emo Traders, is located in an area called Makaburini-Soweto in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is in the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many tourist attractions, including the Indian ocean and its white beaches. Elkanah has been selling items such as rice, flour, oil, detergents, soft drinks, and other things to the local people for the last two years. He says that this business is profitable, and the major challenge he has is security in the area. He is using his loan of KES 20,000 to buy more general items to expand his business. He hopes to be a wholesaler in future, and also to diversify his business to include the transport industry. He describes himself as outgoing and self-reliant.

loans.use: to purchse sugar, flour, detergents, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: Jameela's Group

texts.en:
Jameela, 43, lives in historic Lahore, Pakistan, a city famous for its history and culture. She is married to M. S., and has three sons and a daughter. None of her children could get an education due to financial constraints. Her eldest son started working at an early age to support the family financially. One of her sons is a tailor and the other runs a spare parts shop.

Jameela’s husband sells vegetables and has a shop in the vegetable market. He has been in this business for the last 30 years. His fresh, high-quality vegetables attract customers to his shop. Jameela has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband, who wants to bring more seasonal vegetables into his shop for selling. With the help of this investment her husband will be able to put his business in better condition and increase his income. She is also confident that the increased profits, combined with the savings from her sewing business, will allow her to construct another room in her family’s two-room brick house.

loans.use: to purchase seasonal vegetables for reselling

loans.name: James

texts.en: James M. is 31 years old and married.  His sole source of income comes from operating a matatu (a type of shared taxi or shuttle service) in Mshomoroni, Mombasa. He has been in the business for the last two years. He plans to use this loan, which will be his second from KADET, to purchase new seats for his matatu van. He hopes the anticipated profit will allow him to expand his business and succeed in life.

loans.use: to purchase new seats for his matatu van

loans.name: Primitiva

texts.en:
A dedicated member of ASHI since 2009, Primitiva has been a model member, demonstrating regular attendance at weekly meetings and timely repayments of loans. Since joining ASHI, she has gained more self-confidence as a businesswoman and entrepreneur managing her own venture.

Primitiva buys and sells “amakan” (a word which, in the Antiqueño dialect, refers to woven bamboo strips that are used to dry rice under the heat of the sun). She started this business after joining ASHI. She has built a loyal base of customers in her neighbourhood, and also wants to sell her stock to other provinces. In partnership with her husband, Lino, she transports her products to other provinces through “RORO", or roll on, roll of – a means of transport whereby vehicles that carry passengers and products, particularly buses, roll onto a barge to travel across the ocean and roll off once their destination is reached. 

Primitiva wants to request a much larger loan to support the needs of her business and at the same time to continue its operation. With her passion for giving her family a brighter tomorrow, she will be eager to work hard and help her husband to meet her family’s needs. 

Primitiva’s business has been very helpful in achieving her dreams for her family. Her greatest hope is that her family will be able to have a decent way of life. Her long term goals are to help support her children, to improve her family’s living conditions by investing in and building a better house, and to have a successful business, including a small warehouse for storing the “amakan” she and her husband sell.

loans.use: to support the needs of her business and at the same time to continue its operation

loans.name: Gulshan's Group

texts.en:
Gulshan lives in Lahore, a city famous for its culture. It is the second largest city in Pakistan and the capital of Punjab province. She is the mother of three children – two daughters and a son. Her older daughter is studying in 5th grade and her son is in 2nd grade, while her younger daughter is just 5 years old and has not started to attend school yet. 

Gulshan is living in a small two-room house where she moved after her marriage to D. H.. Her husband has a shop in the market where he sells milk and yogurt. His business is doing well and he is earning a good income. Gulshan has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s business.  This is her 3rd loan with Asasah, and she has proved to be a responsible lendee, never missing any meetings. She has applied for this loan because the holy month of Ramadan (the Muslim month of fasting) has started and the demand for milk and yogurt has almost tripled. In order to supply such a large quantity of milk and yogurt her husband needs to invest in his business. Gulshan is hopeful that with this investment her husband will be able to make the month of Ramadan very profitable.

loans.use: to purchase yogurt and milk for reselling

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en:
Nicholas N. is 45 years old and is married to Rose Nthiga who supports his income. They have seven dependents.

Nicholas operates greengrocery in Kongowea, Mombasa, where most of his customers can easily receive his services. He has been in this business for the last year.

Nicholas hopes to purchase more stock of green vegetables for his greengrocery and to open up other grocery shops in potential areas with the anticipated profit. In future he hopes to be a potential supplier of greengrocery items all over the country.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of green vegetables for his store

loans.name: Aina Razul

texts.en: Aina Razul A. is a married woman who lives in Lada, Barangay Pangbilian, Brookes Point, Palawan. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a general store and a farming business. Aina Razul joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past thirteen loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 16,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,500, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 14th loan, Aina Razul is borrowing PHP 18,000 which she intends to use to pay for more repair and maintenance of her general store so that she can continue to save up for future plans like extending her business and to having a better life. Aina Razul is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: To pay for more repair and maintenance of her general store

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan J. is a 38-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures:  buying and selling vegetables and  electric generator rental businesses. She lives in Purok Lada, Brgy. Pangbilian, Brookes Point, Palawan. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her vegetable and generator businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP16,000. 

Susan is now borrowing PHP 17,000 so that she can purchase another electric generator to rent out. This will be her 14th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Susan aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.
"

loans.use: To purchase new equipment

loans.name: Julius

texts.en: Julius M. is 43 years old. He is a resident of Changamwe Mombasa where he is a poultry farmer. Married to Virginia Rujuru who supports his income, they have two children. Having been in this farming business for four years, Julius hopes to buy chicks and chick mash with the loan from KADET. With the anticipated profit, he wants to buy a juice blending machine. In the future, he hopes to open up a hotel (restaurant) and supply it with the chickens he raises.

loans.use: To buy chicks and chick mash

loans.name: Jambu's Group

texts.en:
Jambu A. is the leader of her group. She is 38 and divorced. She has a daughter and a son. The son is at school and the daughter is not yet in school. In order to make money Jambu prepares and sells various dishes at the market. In this way, she earns 4,000 soms per month. She is also engaged in cattle breeding.  With money received from the loan, Jambu wants to purchase two cows to increase the number of cattle. In the future she wants to increase the number of cattle, open her own cafeteria and build a shed for cattle.

Manzurahon J., 24, is married.  She has a daughter and a son; both of them are preschool age (under 7).  Manzurahon works in a bakery and her husband is a taxi driver. Manzurahon earns 8,000 soms per month.  That profit made it possible for her to save money and purchase a vehicle for her husband. Manzurahon wants to sell her husband’s vehicle, add some money which she saved and purchase another car. But she doesn’t have enough money, so she hopes to obtain the loan.

Mamatkamil I., 55, is married. He has six children; the older daughter is married and lives separately with her family, the second daughter and the older son went to work in Russia and the other children are at school.  Mamatkamil and his wife are engaged in farming. They own some land, so they cultivate various fruits and vegetables. By selling some part of the harvest, Mamatkamil makes 5,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, he wants to purchase fertilizers which are needed for farming.  In the near future, he plans to start repairing his house.

Burulkan M. is the treasurer of the group.  She is 52 and married. She has two daughter and two sons; the first daughter is married and lives separately with her family, the second daughter and the older son went to work in Russia and the youngest son is at school. Two years ago with the initial investment of 7,000 soms,  Burulkan started to breed cattle. Her husband works in construction; he earns 5,000 soms per month. When he is free, he helps his wife with her activity. With money received from the loan, Burulkan wants to start building a shed for cattle. 

,--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase two cows for breeding

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en: Analiza S. is a married woman who lives in Proper 2, Barangay Ipilan, Brookes Point, Palawan. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a general store and selling fruits and vegetables. Her husband, Aswero, who is 36 years old, works as a company driver to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have two children who are 4 and 11 years old. Analiza joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past nineteen loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 20,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 20th loan, Analiza is borrowing PHP 20,000 which she intends to purchase more feeds and raw materials to sell so that she can continue to save for the future education of their children and to uplift their living conditions. Analiza is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more feeds and raw materials to sell

loans.name: Riaz's Group

texts.en:
Riaz is a resident of Lahore, which is the second largest city in Pakistan and very famous for its culture and history. She is a 48-year-old housewife who lives in a three-room brick house with her husband and four children. All three of her sons have left school and have jobs in the factory.

Riaz’s husband has a business selling chicken meat. The demand for chicken increases in Ramadan season (the holy month when Muslims keep fast) so, in order to sell the desired amount of chicken meat, he needs to buy chicken in sufficient quantity. Therefore, Riaz has applied for a loan from Asasah to enable her husband to expand his business. She is hopeful that her husband will be able to improve his business with the help of this investment and his income will be increased.

Riaz’s only daughter is 17 years old and stays at home and manages the household chores. Riaz wants to marry her as she comes to marriageable age, for which she has started collecting dowry. She is very confident that the improvement of her husband’s business will help her in marrying her daughter.

Riaz  is on her 3rd loan and is a very responsible loan user of Asasah. She has maintained good credit behavior and has never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To purchase chickens in large quantity for her husband's business

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: Rita B. is a married woman who lives in Barangay Manghanoy, La Castellana, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a general store , an RTW (Ready-To-Wear) clothing business and a pig-fattening business. Her husband, Alex B., who is 41 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have two children who are 7 and 9 years old. Rita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past ten loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 28,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,000, thus uplifting her family's standard of living. This time, for her 11th loan, Rita is borrowing PHP 29,500 which she intends to use to buy more stock for her general store so that she can continue to save for the future of her family. Rita is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Altanchimeg

texts.en:
Altanchimeg D. is 33 years old and lives with her husband, daughter, and parents-in law in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a traditional nomadic housing tent.

Since 2003, with the help of her husband, Altanchimeg has been operating a meat retailing business at a rented stall in Han Talst, one of the biggest markets in her town. She specializes in selling mutton and beef. She has worked hard to grow her business over the years and now her working capital has reached to 2,500,000 MNT and her daily sales are approximately 400,000 MNT.

As her business is the only source of income for her family, Altanchimeg is focused on improving her skills as a meat retailer and growing her business. She hopes to one day own her own meat-retailing store.

Altanchimeg is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan in order to complete her house which is in the process of being built on a plot of land that she bought with her business revenues.

loans.use: To complete building her house

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en: Fatima R. is from the village of Bolinao. She is 29 years old and is married with one school-aged child. Fatima owns and operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,200 PHP when she sells a raised animal. In 2007, Fatima joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. Fatima is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. This loan will be her 5th from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies

loans.name: Samwelly Chola

texts.en:
Samwelly P. is 42 years old and a timber dealer in Bamburi, Mombasa. He is married to one wife who supports his income, and they have two children.

Samwelly has been in the business for the last four years and being a new KADET member he plans to expand his timber business with the first loan he is requesting. In future he plans to expand more and more with the anticipated profit and succeed in life.

loans.use: to purchase more timber for his inventory

loans.name: Karen Jane

texts.en:
Karen Jane S. is from the village of Brgy. Bonfal West, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 28 years old. Karen Jane is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Karen Jane owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Karen Jane has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Karen Jane joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Karen Jane has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Karen Jane is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will also be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Karen Jane from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Simon Kaila Ole

texts.en:
Simon Kaila Ole N. is 33 years old. He is married to Mary N. and he is the father of four school-going children. Simon is a farmer and he does the farming on his own piece of land which he has been doing for the last ten years.

He learned about KADET through a friend who is a registered  KADET client in his area of residence. This will be his first loan of which he is planning  to spend forty thousand to buy fertilizer and chemicals for his ten acre wheat farm and the remaining twenty thousand shillings to spray the wheat.

He is anticipating  to buy some farm machinery with the anticipated profit from the expanded farming activity.

He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: buy fertilizer and chemicals and spray the wheat

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Arlyn A. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Maharlika, Brgy. Pamantolon, Taytay, Palawan.  She earns her living by operating 3 business ventures:   a vegetable plantation, a general store and a seaweed-culturing business. Her husband, Aldrin A., 41 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. Her vegetable plantation is more than 1 hectare with many different types of vegetables like eggplant, squash and many others. They have 3 children who are 7 to  11 years old. 

Arlyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 2 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Arlyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 6,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 3rd loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000 which she intends to use to purchase more fertilizers and seedlings so that she can continue to save up for the future of her family and business. Arlyn A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.
"

loans.use: purchase of seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan N. is 17 years old and lives in the town of Zanna in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children.   Susan has a business of selling charcoal, which she has had for 6 years.         

To help expand her business, Susan has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more charcoal.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Susan hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her young sisters.  In the future, Susan hopes to own a house. 


Note to lenders: 

BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John N. is 25 years old. He operates a bicycle/motorcycle transport also known locally as `boda boda’ in Changamwe, Mombasa. Married to Muria Mohamed, he solely supports a family of three. 

John N. has been in this business for the last four years and he plans to take his first loan from KADET and add to his savings and purchase a new motorcycle. He  hopes to purchase another motorcycle  and use it in other areas where there is need in Mombasa. In future he would wish to own a passenger service vehicle.

loans.use: add to his savings and purchase a new motorcycle

loans.name: Shazia

texts.en:
Shazia is a 38-year-old lady and comes from a historic city of Pakistan called Lahore. She lives in a small home with her husband and two children in the area called Gul-Bahar colony. Both of her children are daughters; one reads in 6th standard and other is just three years old. Shazia had to leave her education after completing 5th standard due to the poor financial situation of her family but she doesn’t want that to happen with her children. She wants them to complete their education. 

Her husband has a job in a private company and she helps her husband financially by doing embroidery.  She gets regular orders from her neighborhood clients due to the excellence of her work which earns her a very good income. She has fifteen years of experience in this field. 

These days she has a large order to fill for which she wants to buy embroidery materials in bulk. Therefore, she has applied for a loan from Asasah for this purpose. She is very hopeful that she will be able to finish the orders on time  and will make huge profits.  This is her first loan from any MFI and she wants to build a long-term relationship with Asasah.

loans.use: Purchase embroidery items to fill a large embroidery order on time

loans.name: Ngoja

texts.en:
N. M. N. is thirty years old, married, and has one child aged two years old. His business is located at a very busy open-air market called Kongowea in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many tourist attraction sites, not forgetting the Indian Ocean's white beaches. 

He has been selling cloth for the last three years to the local people and tourists. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is during rainy seasons when the market gets too muddy for customers to access his place of business hence low sales. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

He is using his loan of Kes 10,000 to buy more cloth to expand his business. He hopes to grow his business and open many stalls in future. He describes himself as very aggressive.

loans.use: buying more cloth for resale

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam N. is 22 years old and lives in the town of Zana in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is married and has 2 children.  Both of her children are currently in school.  Mariam has a retail shop, which she has had for 3 years.   
      
To help expand her business, Mariam has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase sugar and maize flour for the shop.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Mariam hopes to generate greater profits and buy food for her family.  In the future, Mariam hopes to turn her business into a supermarket.           


Note to lenders: 

BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to buy sugar and maize flour

loans.name: Francis Kirmusoi

texts.en:
Francis Kirmusoi N. is 28 years old. He is a farmer and supports three people in his family. His spouse is Narikuolari N. and they have two children. Narikuolari is a housewife and she helps Francis in his farming activity.

Francis does wheat farming which he has been doing for the last eight years. This will be his second loan and he is planning spend it on preparing his five acre farm for wheat planting.

He is planning to use the anticipated profit from his farming to expand his farming activity by hiring a bigger piece of land to increase his wheat production.

His hopes and dreams are that he will become a large-scale farmer owning a bigger piece of land and be financially able to support his family.

loans.use: preparing five acre wheat farm

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther M. is a 53-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating 3 business ventures:   wholesaler of dried fish, general store and fish vending businesses. She lives in Buena Suerte, El Nido, Palawan. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts.  By working hard in her wholesaler of dried fish, general store and fish vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable.  She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5,000. 

Esther is now borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she can purchase raw materials for her business.   This will be her 3rd loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom.  Esther aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Zanna in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is single and has one child.  Her child is not currently in school.  Mary has a business of food and vegetables, which she has had for less than one year.         

To help expand her business, Mary has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more foods like cassava and 'matooke' (green plantains) for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Mary hopes to generate greater profits and to buy food and medication for her family.  In the future, Mary hopes to own a house.

loans.name: Rejane

texts.en:
Rejane M. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Buena Suerte, El Nido, Palawan. She earns her living by operating one business venture: a bar and restaurant located on the main street of El Nido surrounded by hotel and pension houses of the area and a very affordable restaurant in front of the El Nido Terminal.

Rejane joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past two loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rejane has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. 

Her previous loan of PHP 7,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 20,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 3rd loan, she is borrowing PHP 18,000 which she intends to use to purchase more raw materials so that she can continue to save up for the future of her family and business. Rejane M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en:
Catalina B. is a 65-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures:  buying and selling dried fish and a general store business. She lives in Brgy. Malbago, Madredijos, Cebu. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her dried fish and general store businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable.  She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 4,000. 

Catalina is now borrowing PHP 25,000 so that she can purchase more stock to sell.  This will be her 14th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 18,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Catalina aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way.

loans.name: Naila

texts.en:
Forty-year-old Naila lives in the 2nd largest city of Pakistan, Lahore. She is the mother of four children: three sons and a daughter. Her eldest son is in 5th standard and other two are studying in kindergarten. Her daughter is illiterate. She lives in a small home which consists of three rooms in the area of Gul-Bahar colony. She is married to M. who makes decoration pieces. Naila also helps her husband in his business by making the decoration pieces. She is very good at this art like her husband. 

Naila has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s business. He wants to increase his capacity of making larger amounts of decoration pieces to increase his sales. With the help of a loan, her husband will buy decoration materials such as plaster of Paris and paint etc. in large quantity.
 
Naila is very optimistic that by using his 22 years of experience in this field, her husband will be able to successfully upgrade his business and increase his income. Naila is on her sixth loan and has proved a very responsible loan user of Asasah. In her past five years' loan experience, she has maintained a good credit record and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In this photo, all background vases were made by Naila & her husband.

loans.use: Purchase required items for decoration-making business

loans.name: Marjorine

texts.en:
Marjorine N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Zanna in the Kampala region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children.  Marjorine has a business selling shoes, which she has had for one year.         

To help expand her business, Marjorine has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more shoes.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Marjorine hopes to generate greater profits and buy food for the family.  In the future, Marjorine hopes to own a big hotel.

loans.use: to buy more shoes

loans.name: Billiah

texts.en:
Billiah A. M. supplies building materials. Her business is located at Mtopanga area in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many many tourist attractions, not forgetting the Indian Ocean's white beaches. 

Billiah has been selling such building items as sand, ballast, and coral blocks for the last ten years to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is having to work hard to win the hearts of customers since she is in a business which is male dominated. 

Billiah works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 40,000 to buy more sand, ballast and coral blocks to meet the demand of her customers. She hopes to be a supplier of her goods in future. She also hopes to own a lorry to help her transport the building materials. She describes herself as very determined. 

Billiah is married to a contractor and a mother of four, aged between seventeen years old and five years old.

loans.use: Sand, Ballast, Coral Blocks.

loans.name: Areta

texts.en:
Areta M. is 54 years old and lives in Vanadzor. She has two sons and one daughter. Her daughter is married and lives in Europe. One of her sons is married and lives in another part of Vanadzor. The other son is not married and lives with Areta and her husband. 

Areta and her husband opened their shop across from their house two years ago, but they have been in this business for 12 years. They sell groceries and household goods such oil, paper goods, towels, toys, jam and soap, etc...The profits from the sales allow them to take care of the needs of their family. 

They are seeking a loan of 450,000 Armenian Drams to add more items and a wider selection to their store. She will use the loan money to purchase school supplies in anticipation of the beginning of the school year in September.

loans.use: To purchase school supplies and household goods

loans.name: Magdalina

texts.en:
Magdalina V. is a widow  who lives in Prk. Pasil, Brgy. Mancilang, Madredijos, Cebu City. She earns her living by operating one business venture: a general store  business.  

Magdalina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 12 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Magdalina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 13th loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,500 which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future for family. Magdalina V. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Zanna in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Esther has a business of a beauty salon, which she has had for less than one year. To help expand her business, Esther has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more braids and oil for the hair. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Esther hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes buy food for the family and take care of herself. In the future, Esther hopes to own a house and live a good life. loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en: Mary Ann A. is a married woman who lives in San Jose, Taytayan, Bogo, Cebu. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: wholesaling electronic reloading credits, fattening pigs and operating a tricycle transportation business. Her husband Vicente A. Jr., who is 40 years old, works as a forwarder (Margie's Door to Door Services) to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have one child, who is 17 years old. Mary Ann joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 12 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Mary Ann has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 29,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 20,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 13th loan cycle, she is borrowing PHP 29,500, which she intends to use to pay for more load (mobile-phone credits) so that she could continue to save up for future, build her own house and widen their pig-fattening business. Mary Ann A. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. loans.name: Kuntura Ole

texts.en:
Kuntura Ole N. is 27 years old. He is married to Kinisio N. and he is a father of two children, aged 2 and 6 years. 

Kuntura is a farmer on his own piece of land. He has been farmng for the last seven years.

He learned about KADET from marketing awareness done by KADET staff in his area. This will be his first loan. He is planning to spend 15,000 Kenyan shillings to buy five bags of seeds, 10,000 shillings on harrowing, 10,000 for planting and 15,000 on pesticides. Wheat has proved to be doing very well due to favorable climatic conditions. 

With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to plow more land for farming to increase his wheat production. 

His future dream is that he will become a large-scale wheat farmer in his area. He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To buy five bags of seeds and pesticides and to harrow and plant his field

loans.name: Bayarmagnai

texts.en:
Bayarmagnai B. is 39 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in UlaanB., the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her husband is a self-employed. Their elder daughter is a student, and the younger daughter attends a local middle school. 

Bayarmagnai operates a hair and beauty salon in her town at her own workplace. The business has grown steadily over the years and is a  popular salon in the area. She says, "I would like to improve work condition so my business would attract more attention of my clients and increase the number of comers." Bayarmagnai is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase construction and decoration materials for her hair and beauty salon for innovation and repair.

loans.use: To purchase construction and decoration materials

loans.name: Betty
