To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to increase the range of goods to sell

loans.name: Reginal

texts.en:
Reginal A. is from the village of Salay, Angadanan, Isabela. She is 52 years old. Reginal is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Reginal owns & operates a general store selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Reginal has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Reginal joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Reginal has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Reginal is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Dogbe Françoise

texts.fr: K. Dogbe Françoise est née le 03 octobre 1969 à Zangnanado à Agonli dans le département du Zou au Bénin. Mère de quatre enfants tous scolarisés, Françoise est mariée à HOUNNOU Adrien, un chauffeur. Françoise vit avec sa famille depuis vingt deux ans à Godomey Salamey dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi. Françoise n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Françoise supporte ensemble les charges de la famille avec son mari. Pour y parvenir, Françoise exerce  comme activité principale la vente de fagot de bois depuis une dizaine d'année et pour activité secondaire la vente de tissus, de mèches, et de la nourriture. C'est à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin et dans le marché de Glo que Françoise s'approvisionne pour revendre à son domicile. C'est dans l'objectif d'accroître sa clientèle et son fonds de roulement que Françoise sollicite un premier crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Dogbe Françoise K. was born on 3rd October 1969 in Zangnanado, Agonli in the Zou "département" (administrative district) of Bénin. Mother to four children, who are all at school, Françoise is married to Adrien Hounnou, a driver. She has lived with her family for the past twenty-two years in Godomey Salamey in the municipality of Abomey Calavi. Françoise did not go to school. She covers all the family's expenses together with her husband. In order to do this she has for the past ten years been selling firewood as her main activity, but she also has a secondary activity selling fabrics, hair extensions and food. She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, Bénin's large international market and also in the market at Glo, and she resells her products at home. She is requesting a first loan from ALIDé in order to achieve her goal of increasing her customer base and her working capital.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of three trips to get bundles of firewood

loans.name: Mrs. Chann Yoem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Sixteen people, who live in Damnak village in TaK. province, make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Chann Y., who was born in 1960, is the village bank president, having been selected by the other members. Each member will use their portion of the loan for a different purpose.

Mrs. Chann Y. is a vegetable and pork seller in her local village where she is able to earn a large profit to support her family. She is also a pig breeder while her husband, Mr. Ly Meun, is a farmer who owns a one-hectare (2.5-acre) plot of land that he uses to cultivate rice to sell to support the family.

Since her current business is going sell, Mrs. Chann Y. wants to expand it. So, to achieve this purpose, she is applying for a loan to buy more pork and vegetables to sell. With the rest of the loan she will buy pig feed.

Mrs. Chann Y. is the mother of three children who are attending school and also helping with their parents’ businesses.

loans.use: To buy more pork and vegetable to sell plus feed for her pigs

loans.name: Saijmaa

texts.en: Saijmaa R. is 39 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Uvs province, in the western of Mongolia in a ger, a traditional nomadic housing tent. Her elder child is a student and the younger one attends a local middle school. Her husband helps with the taxi service and flour trading business. Since 2005, the two have been providing transportation throughout their province and from that business, they earn 150,000-200,000 MNT net profit per month. Her husband, Battulga, manages his flour retailing business. He purchases flour in bulk from Bayan-Ulgiy, a neighboring province and resells at retail prices. The two are very hard working and creative people who wish to purchase a big truck in order to import more flour from Russia and become one of the biggest flour suppliers in their town. Saijmaa is requesting an 800,000 MNT loan to purchase a large amount of flour for her business.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of flour

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie T. is from the village of Alimannao, Peñablanca, Cagayan. She is 50 years old. Tessie is married. To make a living, Tessie owns & operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. Tessie has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Tessie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tessie has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. Tessie is requesting a new loan of 22,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Na We This Ii Group

texts.en:
Alhaji M. T. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Alhaji was born in Magburaka town. The 29-year-old is married to a businesswoman and they have two children. One of the children is in primary school and the other is not of school-going age. 

This is not the first loan that Alhaji and his group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. A previous SMT/Kiva loan made a lot of improvement in the lives of these borrowers. However, with the help of this new loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to further improve their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Alhaji is a lorry driver and he has been in this profession for 10 years now. He will use this loan to buy spare parts for his vehicle.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for his vehicle

loans.name: Sangeeta

texts.en:
Sangeeta is a resident of a city called Lahore which is the second largest city of Pakistan. She has lived in the area of Bahar-colony for past six years with her husband and two children. One of her children is receiving an education and attends kindergarten; the second one is not yet of school-going age.

Sangeeta is a nurse but she also does sewing work part-time to supplement her income. Her husband is in the musical profession but on a limited scale. He offers his music to different birthday parties and marriage functions. Currently, he has a CD player and two speakers with whom he plays the music and entertains his clients.

Sangeeta’s husband wants to buy a DJ sound system to improve his business for which Sangeeta has applied for a loan. This would be a first step towards him operating on a large scale and becoming renowned in this field.

Sangeeta is very sure that her husband will be able to increase his income with the help of this new sound system and by giving quality service. She mentioned that her husband has been doing this business for the past ten years and she is very hopeful about his great future.

This is Sangeeta’s second loan. She has been found to be a very good loan user of Asasah.

loans.use: To purchase a DJ sound system for her husband's business

loans.name: Ansorbeh Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT) is very pleased to present to you the members of the “Ansorbeh” group from Makeni. They are people with small-scale businesses who are based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve on their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Ishiatu K.. She is age thirty-one and was born in Makeni city. She is married to a businessman and they have four children – two in primary school and two in secondary school.

Ishiatu sells groundnuts (peanuts), beans, palm-oil (the country’s most favorite cooking oil), etc., and has been running this business for many years now. She will use her share of this loan to buy more groundnuts, palm-oil, beans, etc., in large quantity to add to her stock.

loans.use: To buy more groundnuts, palm-oil, beans, etc., in large quantity

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mylene

texts.en: Mylene F. is from the town of Villa Rose, Cabarroguis, Quirino. She is 31 years old and is married with two school-aged children. Mylene owns and operates a business selling charcoal. She has been engaged in her business for over fourteen years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Mylene joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials needed to make products for sale. Mylene is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase raw materials needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her 2nd from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Victoire

texts.fr: Née en 1967 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, S. Victoire est mariée à FANOU Faustin, un agent de police. Le couple a quatre enfants à charge, tous scolarisés, dont trois sont leurs propres enfants. Victoire vit depuis dix huit ans à Womey dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi, avec sa famille. Le couple subvient ensemble aux différents besoins de la famille. Victoire n'a pas été à l'école. Depuis huit ans, Victoire  mène comme activité la vente de liqueurs et divers produits (lait, sucre, bougies, conserves de sardine, savons, boîtes d'allumettes, etc.) dans sa boutique située dans son quartier. Victoire achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et aussi à Adja au Mono. Victoire a déjà obtenu deux crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés à ALIDé. Dans le but d'élever le niveau de son activité et de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle, Victoire sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un troisième crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1967 in Cotonou, in the economic capital of Benin, Victoire S. is married to Faustin Fanou, a police officer. The spouses have four children in their care, three of whom are their own and all of whom go to school. For eight years, Victoire and her family have been living in Womey in the community of Abomey Clavi. The spouses jointly provide for different family needs. Victoire did not attend school. For the past eight years, her business activity has been selling liqueurs and various products (milk, sugar, candles, canned sardines, soap, matchboxes etc) in her own store located in her neighborhood. Victoire stocks up in Dantokpa, at the international market of Benin, and also in Adja in Mono [a region of Benin]. Victoire already had obtained ALIDé loans twice in the past, and repaid them well. In order to expand her activity and better respond to customer demand, Victoire is seeking a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing 5 boxes of soap, 8 cases of liqueur

loans.name: God-Na-One Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a Kiva partner in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you the members of the “God-Na-One” group. They are seeking a loan of SLL 800,000 each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve on their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Jumah C.. He is age thirty-five and was born in Makeni, where he currently lives with his wife and four children. His wife is a businesswoman and his children are attending schools – two in secondary school and two in primary school.

Jumah sells drinks and cigarettes and has been running this business for two years now. With the help of this loan, he will be able to expand his business by buying crates of drinks and cartons of cigarettes to add to his stock.

loans.use: To buy crates of drinks and cartons of cigarettes to add to his stock

loans.name: Riffat

texts.en:
Riffat J. is a resident of Lahore, which is famous for its gardens and greenery. She is 29 years old and is the mother of two daughters who are of 2 years and 1 year old respectively. She lives in a three-room brick house with her husband and family that they moved into three years ago.

Riffat is a seamstress and does sewing work for her neighborhood customers. She is very good at her art and has a good reputation among her customers for her good work.

Riffat’s husband has a business selling ready-made garments. He operates a shop in the market and sells clothes for gents and children. His business is going very well but he needs further improvement to it because new designs are introduced rapidly in the fashion industry and to keep his shop up-to-date he needs to offer new garment collections, otherwise the other clothes sellers will take the advantage of this which would effect his sales.

Therefore, Riffat has applied for a loan from Asasah to help her husband improve his business. With the loan, he will buy more stock of ready-made garments to sell to his clients. Riffat is very hopeful that her husband will make positive use of the loan and successfully upgrade his business and increase his income.

This is Riffat’s second loan and she has been found to be a responsible loan user of Asasah. She never misses any meetings and has paid her installments on time.

loans.use: To purchase ready-made garments for her husband's business

loans.name: Sisters United Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a Kiva partner in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is pleased to present to you the members of the “Sisters United” group. They are women with small-scale businesses in Waterloo small town, where “Shine on Sierra Leone” partnered with SMT to start a branch. They are seeking a loan of SLL 5,700,000 in order to further develop their businesses.

The leader of this group is thirty-three-year-old Bondu M. who was born in Kono, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. She is married to a police officer and the couple has four children – three in primary school and the last not yet of school-going age.

Bondu, who has been a businesswoman for ten years now, is the owner of a small grocery shop where she sells provisions: sardines, milk, sugar, butter, mayonnaise, bread, etc. She also sells market food such as rice (the country’s staple food), salt, onions, Margi (used to give sauces a sweet taste), etc.

With the help of this loan, Bondu will buy more of the above-mentioned items in large quantity to add to her stock.

loans.use: To buy more sardines, milk, sugar, butter, mayonnaise, bread, rice, salt, onions, Margi, etc.

loans.name: Marcelline

texts.fr: Née en 1978 à Grand-Popo au Bénin, G. Marcelline est mariée à ANATO Emile, un électricien. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille s'est installée depuis quatre ans au quartier Godomey Salamey dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi. Marcelline subvient ensemble avec son mari, aux divers besoins de sa famille, grâce au revenu de son activité. Marcelline n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Il y a deux ans environs que Marcelline a commencé la vente de produits de soins pour bébé et aussi des vêtements bébé. Marcelline achète ses produits à Lomé au Togo et les vend dans sa boutique. C'est la première fois que Marcelline sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un prêt, en vue de rehausser le niveau de son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1978 in Grand-Popo in Benin, Marcelline G. is married to Emile Anato, an electrician. The couple has three children, all of whom go to school. The family has been living for four years in the Godomey Salamey district in the community of Abomey Calavi. Marcelline provides for the family needs alongside her husband, thanks to her enterprise. Marcelline did not go to school. About two years ago, Marcelline started selling baby care products and baby clothing. Marcelline purchases her goods in Lomé in Togo and resells them in her store. This is the first time that Marcelline is seeking a loan from ALIDé, in order to expand her business and better respond to customer needs.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing 5 cartons of baby powder and 10 dozen sets of baby clothing

loans.name: Purevtsend

texts.en: Purevtsend H., age 41, operates a clothing and a household goods business out of a stall in Narantuul, which is the biggest, most crowded market in Ulaanbaatar city. She began her business in 2002 and has been able to increase her family’s earnings greatly over the years since. She would like to eventually increase her profits enough to increase the number of stalls she operates at the market. Purevtsend has a strong entrepreneurial spirit and is requesting a 1,250,000 MNT loan in order to increase her working capital. She lives with her two children in the Chingeltey district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a "ger," which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Both of her two children are students in their town.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing

loans.name: Hiba

texts.en:
Hiba is a 25-year-old woman from Ramallah city. Hiba received her degree and couldn't find a job, therefore she decided to start her own business. With the help of her father and brothers, she rented a small store in the city of Ramallah where she sells mobile phones and accessories.

Hiba took a US$ 1500 loan from FATEN in order to buy more mobile phones to sell as her store is prospering. Most of her customers are woman who feel better dealing with and purchasing from a woman.

Hiba is working very hard and makes sure she saves a good amount of the income as her ambition is to have a big store and expand the range of products she sells. She appears in the picture above in her store.

loans.use: Purchase more goods

loans.name: Kalomp Group

texts.en:
Meet with the members of the “Kalomp” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a Kiva partner, to apply for a loan of SLL 600,000 each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions.

Kadiatu D. is the leader of this group. The forty-seven-year-old is married to a lecturer and they have three children.

Kadiatu is a businesswoman who sells palm-oil (the country’s favorite cooking oil) and rice, and has had many years of experience in business. With the help of this loan, she will buy bags of rice and gallons of palm-oil to add to her stock.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice and gallons of palm-oil to add to her stock

loans.name: Aloysius

texts.en:
He is very hard working and ambitious about owning a big agricultural farm in his home area of Kyarufumbagi. K. Aloysious, aged 42 years, is a peasant farmer who grows food crops, owns a banana plantation and normally sells off his produce to grocery and restaurant business dealers.

Over time he has built a strong attribute of determination that has served him well.  With strong hard-working skills up his sleeves, he has gotten his eight-year-old enterprise a dependable niche in the market, with monthly profits to the tune of about $111. This is what he has been getting since the beginning. 

With this loan he hopes to purchase fertilizers to help improve his agricultural farm and also buy more seedlings for next season. This will in turn improve his yields, hence sales revenue. He will be able to live a more satisfying life and educate his children, which is his main goal.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seedlings

loans.name: Almanzo Group

texts.en:
Shown in the photo are the members of the “Almanzo” group. They are people with small-scale businesses based in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 800,000 each from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve on their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Alimamy D. who is age twenty-seven. He was born in Freetown and is currently living in Magburaka with his wife and his two children who are attending primary school.

Alimamy sells tires and has been doing this for ten years now. With the help of this loan he will buy more spare-parts to add to his business.

Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo.

loans.use: To buy more spare-parts to add to his business

loans.name: Inom

texts.en:
A. Inom is 47 years old and the father of four children. His wife is a housekeeper. Inom owns a field for cultivating watermelon and grapes in order to earn a living. He also raises cattle. 

On his plantation, Inom cannot do any planting because he does not have enough money for seeds and fertilizer. In order to deal with this problem, he decided to ask for a loan of 7,000 TJS. He will use part of the loan for purchasing small cattle. Inom counts on this opportunity to obtain a better yield, to help him improve the living conditions of his family.    

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy small cattle, seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: No One Knows Tomorrow Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a Kiva partner in Makeni, Sierra Leone, is pleased to present to you the members of the “No One Knows Tomorrow” group. They are people with small-scale businesses in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 800,000 each. 

The leader of this group is forty-two-year-old Fatmata F. who was born in Magburaka. She is married to a businessman and the couple has four children who are attending secondary school.

Fatmata owns a small-scale business that sells rice, baking flour, sugar, cold-drinks, and batteries and has been managing this business for fifteen years now. This loan will help her to expand her business by buying more of the above mentioned goods wholesale to add to her stock. 

The group photo also shows loan officer Joseph A. Turay on the right handing over the loan to the group.

loans.use: To buy more rice, baking flour, sugar, cold-drinks, and batteries wholesale to add to her stock

loans.name: Khusen

texts.en:
J. Khusen is 43 years old and lives with his wife and three children. For about sixteen years he has dedicated himself to farming wheat and vegetables. Khusen enjoys being a farmer and finds harvesting his crops especially gratifying. On the other hand, the most tedious parts of farming are the preparation of land for planting and protecting the crop from insects that spoil his harvest. Fortunately for Khusen, his products are in high demand in his area and fetch high prices at the market. 

This is his 5th loan from IMON International. He will use the money to buy seeds and fertilizer for his fields. Khusen thanks all who support him.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Tayagbah Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT) is very pleased to present to you the members of the “Tayagbah” group from Makeni. They are women with small-scale businesses who are based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 800,000 each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve on their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Nanah B. who is age thirty-two and was born in Kamakwe, a town in northern Sierra Leone. She is married and has three children – one of her children is attending primary school, another is in secondary school, and the last is not of school-going age.

Nanah sells rice, palm-oil (the country’s favorite cooking oil), vegetable oil, Margi (used to give sauces a sweet taste), etc., and has been running this business for ten years now. She will use her share of this loan to buy more rice, palm-oil, vegetable oil, Margi, etc., wholesale.

loans.use: To buy more rice, palm-oil, vegetable oil, Margi, etc., wholesale

loans.name: Ashurgul

texts.en:
M. Ashurgul is a loving mother with a great desire to get ahead in life. Her great spirit, strong will and hard work have allowed her to improve her quality of life and that of her family. 

For the past 30 years, this persevering woman has been working very hard at raising and selling cattle, and with the income she generates she provides a better quality of life for her kids, who are her greatest joy. 

Ashurgul asks for a loan of $1,000 in order to buy more young cattle to sell later when they are fully grown. With this investment she will be able to substantially grow her earnings and improve her quality of life.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase more small cattle to raise and sell

loans.name: Sabenty Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Sabenty” group from Makeni, a city in Northern Sierra Leone. They are petty businesswomen who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, in order to seek a loan of SLL 1,200,000 for each in the group. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit and consequently improve their living conditions. 

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Aminata J.. Aminata was born in a place called Sanda. She is thirty-eight years of age. She is married to a businessman and they have four children. Aminata owns a shop wherein she sells mints, lollipops, milk, Maggi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), etc. She will use her share of the loan to add more goods to her business by buying mints, lollipops, cans of milk, Maggi, etc. wholesale.

loans.use: Buy mints, lollipops, cans of milk, Maggi, etc. wholesale

loans.name: Dilorom

texts.en:
Dilorom has a small business selling clothing. She is married with one son and has been in business for nine years. She is an energetic, enthusiastic entrepreneur who operates her business simply but wisely. An example of this is times when she has needed to purchase new clothing inventory. Rather than close her business and travel herself to buy inventory, she has paid other clothing vendors to buy for her so that she can stay and keep her business open. 

Dilorom has requested a loan to help renew her supply of clothing inventory. This loan will help her purchase a good supply of clothing to sell so she can maximize her profits and continue working to develop her business.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing new goods for selling.

loans.name: Otajon

texts.en:
S. Otajon is 38 years old. He is married and has two children. His goals are to grow in his personal life and in his business. His wish is to offer better service to his customers. His dream is that God continues to provide him with more life to get ahead and to fulfill his goals. 

He is a taxi driver and travels through the streets of Istaravshan, Tajikistan, in search of customers. He has owned his business for five years. Currently Otajon’s car needs some repairing and he wants to borrow $2,000. The financing will go towards repairs of his vehicle, and he will also purchase new tires. He thanks Kiva and all lenders that make this help possible.      
 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing spare parts for repairs on his car.

loans.name: Urjinsuren

texts.en:
Urjinsuren J. lives with her husband in Central province of Mongolia in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, and she operates a consumer goods retailing business with the help of her husband. Her husband is a plumber for the local Heating Station and is employed with a salary of 310,000 MNT per month. 

She began her business in 2009 with working capital of 1,000,000 MNT. Since then, she has been working hard to operate her business and her working capital has grown to exceed 2,500,000 MNT. 

She would like to grow her business in order to sell vegetable products as well and be able to save money for purchasing an apartment so that she can improve her quality of life. Urjinsuren is the kind of person who is hard working and modest. 

She is requesting a 1,400,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a variety of food products at wholesale prices and to increase her working capital as well.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of food products to sell

loans.name: Komyeneh Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Komyeneh” group from Magburaka, a town in Northern Sierra Leone. They are petty businesspeople who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, in order to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 for each in the group. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit and consequently improve their living conditions. 

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Hawanatu T.. Hawanatu was born in Mayorloh village about twenty-seven years ago. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a businessman and her children are attending primary school. Hawanatu has had eight years of experience in business. She sells cigarettes, batteries, toothpaste, bars of soap, etc. She will use her share of the loan to buy batteries, toothpaste, bars of soap, etc. wholesale to add to her current inventory. 

(Attached to this photo is are snapshots of some borrowers who were not able to be present for the group photo.)

loans.use: Buy batteries, toothpaste, bars of soap, etc. wholesale

loans.name: Aizada

texts.en:
Aizada O. is a resident of Balykchi, a nice town in the Isykul region. She is 24 years old and she is married. She has a three-year-old daughter. 

Aizada and her husband are private entrepreneurs. They started their business activity five years ago with the initial investment of 700 KGS.  Aizada sits at home and accepts ferrous and nonferrous metal, and her husband sells that metal in China. In this way they earn about $650 per month.  That profit made it possible for them to save money and purchase a house, a piece of land in Bishkek and a big truck. 

Aizada applied for the loan because she needs money to increase the turnover in their family business. In the future she wants to give her daughter a good education and build a house in Bishkek. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase more metal to sell

loans.name: Go Ahead Group

texts.en:
Meet members of the “Go Ahead” group from Magburaka, a town in Northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of SLL 3,100,000. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Mohamed T. is the leader of this group. The forty-one-year-old is married to a businesswoman and they have two children. Mohamed has been a businessman for many years now. He sells medicines.  With his share of this loan, he will buy a large number of medicines to add to his current ones.

loans.use: Buy medicines wholesale

loans.name: Dolgor

texts.en:
Dolgor D. is 46 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in Hovd province in western Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger - a traditional nomadic housing tent. 

She initially worked as a saleswoman in Han-Ord, a local market, but since 2005 she has been managing her own business, retailing food products at the same market in her town. She began operating her business with her the savings from her salary, and today her working capital reaches to one million MNT. 

Dolgor is a very hardworking woman who has managed to build her own house with her business profits, and she is planning to open a small food shop in her town. Her husband works for a local construction company, which is considered profitable during the summertime. However the construction work is very seasonal, so he raises cattle during the other seasons. 

Dolgor is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan in order to purchase fruits in bulk to resell at retail prices.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits in bulk

loans.name: Elom A.

texts.en:
Since 2002, Madame Aziagbe has been a seamstress near her home in Lome, Togo. She purchases pagnes, a traditional wax-printed cloth, and basin, a more expensive, high quality cloth used for dresses here in Togo, and then uses them to create clothing for her clients. 

She is requesting a loan of 300,000 XOF in order to purchase more fabric. She plans to divide the loan evenly between purchasing pagnes and purchasing basin. 

Madame Elom A. is 33 years old. She is married and she and her husband have one child.

loans.use: To purchase basin and pagnes, traditionally used fabrics in Togo

loans.name: Nadir

texts.en:
Nadir M. is a very hard working man who comes from Imishli city. After having been rejected for various jobs he decided to start his own business providing wrought iron services. He started it five years ago. The good service that he offers has brought him a lot of clients and now he employs someone to help him meet his clients’ needs. His monthly income is about $500 - $750. His primarily orders are iron doors and window security bars, which are very popular among Azerbaijani people. 

Nadir’s desire is to keep growing, and in order to do this he is asking for a loan of 1,000 AZN to refurbish his shop and to buy some equipment. In this way he can improve the quality of service that he offers so that his business can continue to grow.

loans.use: to refurbish his shop and buy some equipment

loans.name: Seymur

texts.en:
Seymur M. is an iron shop owner and has two years of experience in this field. Seymir is only 29 but already is a master at his work. He has a lot orders from local people and the quality of his products is very high. 

Seymur is married and has two children. His monthly income is about $500 to $700. He applied for a loan of 1,000 AZN to purchase more iron so as to increase the number of orders.

loans.use: purchase more iron

loans.name: Narantsatsral

texts.en:
Narantsatsral S. is 29 years old and lives with her husband and four children in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in Central province of Mongolia. Narantsatsral and her husband have four children, one of whom is adopted from their sister who died. 

Narantsatsral participated in a vegetable-pickling training organized by Development Solutions NGO, and she has decided to operate her own business with the cooperation of her friend who grows vegetables and fruit in a greenhouse. The co-workers are planning to produce partially processed vegetables by pickling and preserving, and provide them to the local market as labeled products.  This is permitted by the local inspection authority.  

Her husband works as a shoemaker in a local private company with a monthly salary of 250,000 MNT. Narantsatsral is a very hard-working and modest woman who would like to expand her business even further in the future. She is requesting a 750,000 MNT loan in order to purchase necessary tools and materials for her vegetable pickling process.

loans.use: To purchase necessary tools and materials for her vegetable pickling process

loans.name: Adjoa Clarisse

texts.en:
Madame Adjoa Clarisse L. has worked since 2000 selling various items. Currently, she is in the business of selling candy in bulk, as well as pagnes - a Togolese wax printed cloth worn by most women here in Togo. As a distributor, she benefits from being able to purchase her food merchandise, like candy, in bulk. 

For this reason she is requesting a loan of 300,000 CFA which she will divide between purchasing candy and purchasing pagnes. With her increased income, Madame L. will provide for her only child of whom she is the sole caretaker.

loans.use: To purchase candy and pagnes, a traditional Togolese cloth

loans.name: Oussama

texts.en:
Oussama is a 34-year-old married man living in Bint Jbeil with his wife and three children. He works as a plumber with 20 years of experience, on his own for 17 years. 

This is the 2nd time Oussama has requested a loan from Al Majmoua.  He is requesting a loan in order to buy a Rapid, a useful car that will make his travel to his appointments easier. 

Oussama’s clients can be anyone in need of his plumbing services. What specializes him among his competitors is his experience and his honesty in his work and in his appointments, unlike most plumbers. 

He hopes to expand his work and to start taking jobs with big construction projects in the future.

loans.use: To buy a Rapid (car)

loans.name: Karim

texts.en: Karim S. is only 23 years old but already runs his own business of plastic windows and doors. He is making it on his own.  He has two years of experience in this field. Karim`s monthly income is about $250-$450 and he would like to increase it to $625. For this purpose he applied for a loan of 1,000 AZN. He wants to build his own shop and not have to pay rent.

loans.use: to build his own shop

loans.name: Djabir

texts.ru:
Djabir Yavlyayetsya IDP personom , on pereselenec iz okupirovannix territoriy Azerbaydjana iz Fuzuli, Seychas on projivayet v Fuzuli regione poselok Bala-Bahmanli. Djabir A. 28 let. On ne jenat i jivet so svoyey semyoy.

Djabir nachal zanimatysa skotovodstvom 5 let tamu nazad posle toqo kak eqo otec zabolel. Etomu biznessu eqo nauchil eqo otec  s detstva. Seychas Djabir nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit korov. Djabir sam delayet sir i yoqur i prodayet.
texts.en:
Djabir A. is an internally displaced person. He is a refugee from Azerbaijan’s occupied territories in Fuzuli. At present he lives in the village of Bala-Bahmanli in the Fuzuli region. He is 28 years old. He is single and lives with his relatives. Djabir started raising cattle five years ago, after his father had fallen ill. He has learned this trade from his father, from his childhood on. At present he needs 2000 Azerbaijani Manats in order to buy cattle. Djabir makes his own cheese and yogurt for sale.

Translated from Russian by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing cattle

loans.name: Nabih

texts.en:
Nabih is a 24-year-old married man, the father of one child, working in the construction field since 2002. He works as a builder, too, specializing in working with a certain kind of stone. 

This is his 1st time to request a loan from Al Majmoua. He wants to buy a Rapid; a useful car that will ease his travel to work. Nabih believes that this car will increase his job assignments and expand his working area.

loans.use: to buy a Rapid (car)

loans.name: Adjovi

texts.en:
Madame Adjovi B. works at her general store in Lome, Togo, where she sells a range of grocery items and merchandise. Currently she is selling home products like soap, detergent, and other cleaning products. She would like to add food products like oil, sugar, canned goods, and other items to her merchandise. 

For this reason, she has requested a loan of 300,000 XOF in order to purchase these products for her store. She normally purchases her provisions at the Grand Market in Lome. Madame B. is married to an electrician and they have one child.

loans.use: To purchase products to sell at her general store

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
As an owner of a clothing shop since 2006 with 6 years of experience, this 26-year-old single man believes that he has achieved an important level in his business. Ali is a businessman from Bint Jbeil who started his small business at the age of twenty, and he is proud of himself. 

Most of his clients are soldiers from the Indonesian Army, who believe that his clothing style suits them a lot, and that he is friendly to the utmost level. 

This is Ali’s 2nd time to request a loan from Al Majmoua, and he is a man of good standing. He is requesting a loan in order to increase his capital and to put up a new glass storefront. He hopes to expand his business through opening new branches or through starting a wholesale business.

loans.use: To increase his capital and erect a glass storefront

loans.name: Kudratilla

texts.en:
Kudratilla A. is a resident of Kadamjai, a nice town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. He is 35 years old, married, and he has a two-year-old daughter.  

Seven years ago, with the initial investment of 7,000 KGS, he started to breed livestock. Selling some sheep after fattening, he makes about $108 per month.  That profit made it possible for him to save money and start repairing his house.  

With money received from the loan he wants to purchase four sheep and four goats in order to increase the numbers of his livestock.  In the future Kudratilla plans to open an auto repair station. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase four sheep and four goats

loans.name: Jambila

texts.en:
Jambila S., age 48, and her husband are cattle breeders in Kadamjai, a town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. They started this activity six years ago with an initial investment of 10,000 soms. With the money received from the loan, Jambila wants to purchase building materials to repair the shed and finish repairing her house. In the future, she plans to increase the number of cattle and to start repairing her shop. The couple has raised three daughters, all of whom are now working in Russia. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line:

Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase building materials for cattleshed repairs

loans.name: Gulnara

texts.en:
Gulnara J., age 39, raises livestock in Kadamjai, a town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She started to breed livestock six years ago with an initial investment of 5,000 soms. By selling the sheep she has raised, she makes 3,000 soms per month. Her husband works in Russia and he helps her to cover family expenses. With the money received from the loan, Gulnara wants to purchase four sheep to increase her number of livestock. She will also use part of the loan to purchase building materials to start repairing her house. She has a daughter and a son, both of whom attend school. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious, and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: 
- People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), 
- Planet (keeping environmentally friendly), and 
- Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). 
MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in central Asia, please join our Lending Team, "Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance," at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase four sheep

loans.name: Buusara

texts.en:
Buusara T., age 49, is a cattle breeder in Kadamjai, a town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. Buusara has raised two daughters and two sons, all of whom are now working in Russia with their father. Buusara started to breed cattle four years ago with an initial investment of 10000 soms. By selling milk, she makes 3,000 soms per month. Buusara also breeds other livestock, and with the money received from this loan, she plans to purchase four sheep to increase the number of livestock. She will also use part of the loan to cover family expenses. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious, and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line:

MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in central Asia, please join our Lending Team, "Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance," at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase four sheep

loans.name: Samir

texts.en:
Samir, age 33, lives in Bint Jbeil with his wife and their only child. Samir earns his living by repairing cars. This is a business he has been engaged in since 1998. In total, he has 15 years of experience in this kind of work. 

Samir is requesting his first loan from Al Majmoua in order to update his machines and expand his business. Samir is professional in his work and expects to grow his business in the future through opening a larger car maintenance company. 

His goal is to provide security and a good standard of living for his family.

loans.use: To update his car repair equipment

loans.name: Djemila

texts.en:
Madame Djemila M. sells pots, pans, and other cooking utensils at the Agoe Market in Lome, Togo. She has been engaged in this activity since about 2004. This is a lucrative business because of how useful and in demand such products are. 

Madame M. has requested a loan in the amount of 500,000 CFA in order to purchase cooking utensils as well as plastic bins and basins to sell at her stall. 

She is married to a customs officer and they have three children.

loans.use: To purchase utensils and plastic items to sell

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad, age 36 and married, has been working as a barber since 1996. In total, he has 17 years of experience in this field. This is the third time Ahmad has requested a loan from Al Majmoua, and has used his loans to order and buy necessary merchandise for his business in addition to paying house-building costs. Ahmad likes his work a lot and believes that as long as he takes care of his quality of business, his business will expand. He hopes to own a larger and even more successful barber shop someday.

loans.use: To buy necessary merchandise for his business

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence owns a stall in Kalerwe market, where she sells tomatoes and onions. She buys her baskets of tomatoes from the very market where she works and so doesn’t incur any transport costs. She would like to use this loan to buy more baskets of tomatoes and onions for sale. She has been in this business for three years and has worked with MCDT for almost two years. She initially joined MCDT to acquire additional capital. This will be her fourth loan. 

Florence aspires toward seeing her business grow bigger and hopes eventually to be able deal directly with farmers when purchasing her wares. Her primary business challenge is seasonality, a problem partially addressed by her other business endeavor: bicycle rental. In addition to her tomato vending business, she hires out bicycles. This allows her to earn additional income, as she is able to hire out a bicycle for 2,000 per day.

Florence is married and has five children, four of whom attend school. She resides in a rented one-roomed house, where the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her primary monthly expenses includes school fees, rent, and food.

loans.use: To buy more baskets of  tomatoes and onions for sale

loans.name: Shakir

texts.ru:
Shakir Jivet v Fuzuli Regione. Shakir M. 40 let. On jenat i imeyet 2 detey , Doch 18 let uchitsya v universitete i sin 13 let kotoriy uchitsya v shkole i zanimayetsya nacionalnimi tancami. 

Shakir uje 8 let kak rabotayet v etom maqazine. Etomu biznesu eqo nauchil brat kotoriy toje imeyet svoy maqazin po eqo sovetu i Shakir otkril sebe maqazin. Seychas Shakir nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chto bi uvelichit pomesheniye v svoyom maqazine. Po eqo slovam maqazin malenkiy i on ne mojet pomeshat tuda noviye tovari.
texts.en:
Shakir M. lives in the Fuzuli region. Shakir is 40 years old. He is married and has two children. His daughter, 18 years old, studies at the university, and his 13-years old son goes to school and also learns traditional dancing. Shakir has been working in this store for eight years already. His brother who keeps a store taught him this business, and it was on his brother’s advice that Shakir opened his own store too. At present Shakir needs 2000 Azerbaijani Manats in order to expand his store space. He says that that the store is too small and space for new goods is lacking.

Translated from Russian by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expanding the store space

loans.name: Essotina

texts.en: Monsieur Essotina T., age 25, works from his home selling school supplies and clothing. He has been in this business for the last five years. In order to prepare for the upcoming school year, Monsieur T. is planning to purchase five boxes of various school supplies - notebooks, pens, school books, and other items - that university students and secondary school students will buy as they prepare to go back to school for the year. To this end, Essotina has requested a loan of 400,000 CFA to help him purchase school supplies. This is his first time requesting a loan from Kiva's field partner WAGES.

loans.use: To purchase school supplies for sale

loans.name: Beeda

texts.en:
Beeda owns a small eating establishment at the market in Bwaise, where she sells food items. She has been in this business for ten years. She buys her foodstuffs from the very market where she works and sells to all categories of people at retail prices. She wants to use this loan to buy more  cooking utensils and to purchase necessary foodstuffs like bunches of bananas, cassava, rice, and beef. She also hopes to buy a charcoal stove. Beeda decided to join MCDT because of the low interest charged.

She works six days a week. Her primary business challenge is the rainy season, because when it rains, her customers don’t reach out to her. She aspires toward owning a large hotel and is determined eventually to improve her family's standard of living. 

Beeda is married with six children. She also takes care of the three orphaned children of her late sister. She resides in a rented two-roomed house and the family has access to electricity but has no piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

loans.use: To buy more cooking utensils, essential foodstuffs, and a charcoal stove for her business

loans.name: Zaur

texts.ru:
Zaur S. 29 let. On ne jenat . Zaur Jivet v Absheron regione vmeste so svoyey semyoy. Zaur uje 4 qoda tomu nazad nauchilsya etomu biznesu prodaji materialov u svoyeqo otca  kotoriy prodoval zanavest. 

3 Qoda spustya Zaur reshil otkrit svoy maqazin i prodovat materiali. Sychas Zaur nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi rasshirit pomesheniye maqazina. Po eqo slovam iz za toqo chto pomesheniye malenkoye on no mojet imet mnoqo tovara  a yesli pomesheniye budet bolshim on smojet privozit i prodovat razniye noviye tovari.
texts.en:
Zaur S. is 29 years old. He is single. Zaur lives in the Absheron region with his family. Four years ago, Zaur learned his business of selling building materials from his father who sold curtains. After three years, Zaur decided to open his own store and sell materials. Now, Zaur needs 2000 AZN to expand the size of his store. According to him, because he has such a small shop he cannot stock many items, but if it were bigger, he would be able to bring in and sell new and different goods.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing shop size

loans.name: Mwendia

texts.en:
Mwendia is a hardworking farmer from the town of Kisii in Western Kenya. He has been operating his mixed farm for the last 25 years. His farm produces tea, coffee, maize and beans which he sells to Kenya Tea Development Authority and at the local market. He mainly depends on the income from his farming activities to cater for the needs of his family.

Mwendia has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 45,000 Kenyan Shillings to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The proceeds from this investment will help him pay school fees for his son in college. The family will also be able to have enough milk for consumption.

His biggest challenges have been diseases which attack his poultry and animals like dogs which attack and feed on his poultry. In future, he would like to acquire more dairy cows and increase the stock of poultry.

Mwendia is 60 years old. He is married with 5 children who are all adults.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a farmer from the town of Kisii town in Western Kenya. She has been practising mixed farming for the last 30 years. Her farm produces milk, bananas, tea and coffee which she sells at the local market. She depends on the income from her farming activities to cater for the needs of her family.

Mary is 51 years old. She is married with 5 children who are now between the ages of 16 and 30. Her youngest child is still attending school.

Mary has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 45,000 Kenyan Shillings to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from the sale of milk will enable her to pay school fees for her child. She faces the challenge of lack of enough capital to expand her business.

In five years' time, she would like to expand her farm in order to increase her sources of income.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Adjo

texts.en:
Madame Adjo D. sells health products and medicines at her small store in Lome, Togo. She has been in this business since 2008 and is looking to expand a little. She is ready to take her second microloan from WAGES and has requested 500,000 CFA in order to purchase many different kinds of products to sell as merchandise in her shop. 

Madame D. is the sole caregiver for her only child, and so any increased income she receives as a result of your investment in her business will allow her to better care for her child.

loans.use: To purchase medicines and other products

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: The purchasing of more clothes for resale

loans.name: Flora

texts.en: Flora J. is currently in the business of selling local Sudanese green vegetables such as 'korofo', 'kombo' and okra at the market and is requesting a loan to stock dried fish to sell.  Flora is 35 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to initiate another type of business, mainly selling charcoal.

loans.use: Stock dried fish to sell

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is married and has 3 children.  Two of her children are currently in school.  Lydia has a beauty salon, which she has had for 2 years.         

To help expand her business, Lydia has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more braids (hair extensions) and oil for the hair.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Lydia hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes pay school fees for her children.  In the future, Lydia hopes to own a house and to see her child attend university.  Lydia is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by not letting her sit at home but have something to do (become self reliant).

Note to lenders: 

BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to buy hair extensions and  hair oil

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace A. is currently in the business of selling bread, fried fish and tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more fresh fish and tomatoes to sell.  Grace is 20 years old and is single.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent out.

loans.use: Stock more fresh fish and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Immaculate

texts.en:
Immaculate is a fruit vendor, selling jackfruits, sugarcane, mangoes, and other such fruits in Ndeeba on the outskirts of Kampala. She buys her wares from the villages of Mukono District, and she uses public transportation to and from making these purchases. Transportation is therefore somewhat of a challenge, as is seasonailty. She has been in this business for seven years and works seven days a week. She decided to join MCDT because they were offering timely loans. She wants to use this loan to buy more jackfruits and bundles of sugarcane.

Immaculate is married to a boda-boda cyclist (motorcycle chauffeur)  and they have five children, all of whom attend school. She aspires toward educating her children up to the university level. The family resides in a rented two-roomed house; the family has no access to electricity or piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, rent, and food.

loans.use: To buy more jackfruits and bundles of sugarcane

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Elizaya

texts.en: Elizaya S. is currently in the business of selling various raw foods such as cassava, yams, Irish potatoes, etc. at the market and is requesting a loan to stock maize flour and rice to sell.  Elizaya is 40 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a retail shop.

loans.use: Stock maize flour and rice to sell

loans.name: Claire

texts.en:
Claire N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is married and has 3 children.  All of her children are currently in school.  Claire runs a small eatery, which she has had for 2 years.         

To help expand her business, Claire has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more saucepans and stock food.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Claire hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes buy food and school fees.  In the future, Claire hopes to own a big restaurant. Claire is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by managing to provide the home needs in a timely manner. 

Note to lenders: 

BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of food

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en: Lucia J. is currently in the business of selling various items in a shop such as cartons of salt, boxes of soap, etc.  and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of sugar and cartons of salt to sell.  Lucia is 36 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

loans.use: Stock more bags of sugar and cartons of salt to sell

loans.name: Tutungukye Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
Very hard working, M. Moses has been operating an agro-produce sales business from Omukagyera, Ibanda for a period of 10 years. With nostalgia, this happily married father of two children recalls how his business basked in high profit returns at its onset. Times have changed, however, as the business now is in diminishing returns, earning him 150,000 Ugandan shillings in sharp contrast to previous earnings due to seasonal changes.

Moses is no exception herein in terms of doing business. What he is looking forward to now is the prospect of enhancing his business by buying fertilizer and improving the production of beans and maize which he grows most. He has other income generating activities like a bar and a butcher shop. With this loan, he will improve his production and can afford business expansion. His revenue will increase and also he can make himself more able to meet his day-to-day life and family necessities.

loans.use: buying fertilizers to improve production

loans.name: Madina

texts.en:
Madina N. is 16 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children. Madina has a little eatery, which she has had for 6 years.         

To help expand her business, Madina has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more food and other stock for the eatery.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Madina hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes buy food.  In the future, Madina hopes to complete university. Madina is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by having time to share experience with her friends at the club and enjoying reading story books rather than doing nothing. 

Note to lenders: 

BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to buy food etc. for her eatery

loans.name: Reida

texts.en: Reida Y. is currently in the business of selling bags of maize, rice, and millet at the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of sorghum to sell.  Reida is 35 years old and is married to a husband who is a soldier. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a store to sell her cereals in.

loans.use: Stock bags of sorghum to sell

loans.name: Ramatu

texts.en:
Ramatu is married and has two children. She first established a foodstuffs business, with a small business capital provided by her husband. She later changed to selling ready-made clothes after accumulating enough money from her first business. Ramatu has been selling ready-made clothes for the past ten years in the Silvanus market, Makeni city.  

Ramatu has a good credit history. She needs a loan of 4,000,000 SLL to help her buy various types of clothes, so that she can meet the demand of her customers who normally buy more for the Ramadan season. Ramatu intends to use the proceeds of her loan to educate her children and buy a vehicle for transportation. She thanks you for supporting her.

loans.use: To buy additional items for her business.

loans.name: Placide

texts.fr:
M. Placide, née à Kigali  secteur Kagarama en district de Kicukiro dans la province de ville de Kigali du Rwanda, il est marié, il a 4 enfants, il a 36 ans, son ainé a 12  ans et son dernier enfant à 5 ans et  son niveau d’éducation est primaire. Il habite à Kicukiro avec sa famille. Tous ces enfants vont à l’école. Son épouse  fait le commerce de détail en  boutique pour aider son mari de faire vivre sa famille et pouvoir améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. Il effectue ce commerce de transport des personnes sur moto à Kigali .Il vient de contracter un prêt au sein d’Amasezerano pour finir sa maison qui n’avait pas de plafond et n’était pas peint.
Il fait les épargnes, une partie du profit est  épargne pour les études de ses enfants et supporter la capacité  financière de sa femme. Il a pu construire une maison grâce aux épargnes continuelles.
texts.en:
Placide M. was born in the Kigali sector of Kagarama which is in the Kicukiro district of Kigali City Province in Rwanda. He is 36 years old, married and has 4 chlidren. His oldest child is 12 years old and his youngest child is 5. He has an elementary school education. He lives in Kicukiro with his family. All of his children go to school. His wife works in a retail shop to help her husband support the family and to improve their living conditions. He runs a business of transporting people to Kigali by motorcycle. He just took out a loan from Amasezerano to finish his house which didn’t have a roof and wasn’t painted. He saves some money; a part of his profit is saved for the education of his children and to bolster the financial resources of his wife. Thanks to his continual savings, he was able to build a house.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy planks and paint colors

loans.name: Vicky

texts.en: Vicky P. is currently in the business of selling bananas, yams, carrots and sweet potatoes and is requesting a loan to stock cassava, fruit such as jack fruits, and Irish potatoes to sell.  Vicky is 32 years old and is married to a husband who is a soldier. She has two children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar.

loans.use: Stock cassava, fruit such as jack fruits, and Irish potatoes

loans.name: Kasharara Bakyara Twimukye, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
In a certain village of Bwera, Ibanda there is a determined lady named T. Christine, aged 39 years, a go-getter businesswoman who has been dealing in general merchandise in a retail shop. This stickler for hard work is also a married mother of 3 school-going children and has been running her business for over 2 years. With this experience behind her, she has managed to subdue most of the uncertain adversities that have threatened to play havoc with her business. In a month, her business generates a profit of 240,000 Ugandan shillings. 

This to all intents and purposes is a low figure. What has helped her as she operates her business have been her exceptional customer relationship skills. Now, she is taking a long view with an aim of maximizing her small profits. She figures this loan will come in handy in helping her buy more stock as currently she sells small household items like sugar, soap, and so on.

loans.use: buying more stock  like sugar, salt, soap and many other items for resale

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary K.  is currently in the business of selling dresses, trousers, and bedsheets in an open place at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bedsheets and trousers to sell.  Mary is 41 years old and is married to a husband who is a policeman. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a shop as a sales point.

loans.use: Stock more bedsheets and trousers to sell

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa has recently decided to change her business enterprise from charcoal sales to fish vending. She has been in this new business for a few months. She works in the very market where she used to sell charcoal. She buys fish from the Gaba landing site in Makindye Division in Kampala District. Her primary business challenge is the transport of fish from Gaba to her stall in Owino market, a journey for which she presently uses public transportation. She works six days a week. She wants to use this loan to buy more baskets of fish. She aspires toward a business model of selling solely at wholesale prices. She decided to work with MCDT because she wanted to boost her business by obtaining additional capital. 

Hawa resides in a rented two-roomed house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, food, and rent. She is a single mother and has three children, all of whom attend school. She lives in Mengo Kisenyi in the outskirts of Kampala city. It is a walkable distance from Kampala city to her residence.

loans.use: To buy more baskets of fish for sale

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace Y. is currently in the business of selling bread, fried sweet potatoes and groundnut paste at the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of local Sudanese ful (fava) beans to sell.  Grace is 30 years old and is married with a husband who is a peasant. She has four children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

loans.use: To stock bags of local Sudanese ful beans to sell

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en: Amelia M. is currently in the business of selling bags of groundnut and soya beans at the market.  She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of soya beans and some bags of rice to sell.  Amelia is 37 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has two children, both of whom go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to care for her family by providing a food stall.

loans.use: To stock more bags of soya beans and some bags of rice to sell

loans.name: Hirally

texts.en:
